**Noel McKenna**  
born Australia 1956

**William Nuttall with horses in field** 2023  
oil on canvas

â€˜Bill Nuttall has been one of my dealers since 1985.â€™

Noel McKenna lives and works on Gadigal Country in Sydney. His subject matter is drawn from the everyday, often depicting the relationship between humans and animals.
oil and synthetic polymer paint on canvas\n\nÂ© The artist

**Mark Tweedie**  
born Australia 1982

**Vagabond #10** 2023  
oil and synthetic polymer paint on canvas

â€˜Vagabond #10 is my breakup painting. The work has grown from my feelings of being disconnected, alone and in many ways, nomadic, and is an exploration of a longing for home that has deepened with age. The landscape depicted is the John Forrest National Park, located on the outskirts of Boorloo/Perth, Western Australia; a place I would often visit but never felt at home. The composition references a photograph by Violet Joyce, first published in Perthâ€™s _Western Mail_ newspaper in the early 1900s.â€™

Mark Tweedie is a Boorloo/Perth-based artist whose work is characterised by themes of family, memory and ageing, often exploring formative childhood years, connection to place and lineage.

labels.title: In reverence of comedic wisdom â€“ Gerard Lee
labels.subtitle: Surya Bajracharya

text.content: dry-brushed charcoal\n\nÂ© The artist

**Surya Bajracharya**  
born Nepal 1979, Australia from 1984

**In reverence of comedic wisdom â€“ Gerard Lee** 2023  
dry brushed charcoal on paper

â€˜_In reverence of comedic wisdom_ is a portrait of Gerard Lee, cherished family friend, mentor and writer. In recent years, Gerard and I have come back into closer contact, and he has offered me counsel and hope for a way forward. This is how I see him in my portrait, determined, thoughtful, optimistic, with a droll comment waiting in the wind. A reply from Gerard during the portrait-making process: â€œLook, I built the face, from pain and agony and the ability to look beyond all that into the wide blue yonder â€¦ Whatâ€™s it worth to you? Whatâ€™s the prize money? Whatâ€™s my cut?â€â€™

Kamberri/Canberra-based artist Surya Bajracharyaâ€™s practice encompasses printmaking, painting and sculpture and oscillates between place, politics and personal experience.
oil on canvas\n\nÂ© The artist

**Sarah McCloskey**  
born Australia 1992

**Golden hour** 2024  
oil on canvas

â€˜This is a portrait of my dear friend Jack. Ever since I moved to Sydney in 2019, Jack has been an invaluable friend to me through many difficult times. He has always been willing to indulge in my projects and is ever-encouraging along the way. This portrait came out of a sitting at my studio last year, shortly before Jack moved to Melbourne. At the time there was a lot on both of our plates, and we spent a few hours talking and enjoying the changing afternoon light. This stripped-back portrait captures a candid moment of Jack in thought, with the warm glow of sunset illuminating his face.â€™

Sarah McCloskey is an artist from Western Australia who lives and works on Wangal Country in Sydney. McCloskeyâ€™s portraiture evokes and highlights themes of familiarity, connection and universal human experiences.

labels.title: Ken telling a story, radiating glory
labels.subtitle: Claudio Kirac
labels.medium: synthetic polymer paint, aerosol and oil

text.content: synthetic polymer paint, aerosol and oil on primed canvas\n\nÂ© The artist

**Claudio Kirac**  
born Australia 1976

**Ken telling a story, radiating glory** 2024  
oil, synthetic polymer paint and aerosol on canvas

â€˜I sat with Ken as he leaned into one of his many amazing stories, with a confidence and smile mustered from years of experience on this earth. He told a story that I had heard before on a podcast, read in a book or saw on TV but, sitting in the presence of greatness, who am I to stop him? Ken Done and I, while operating in different realms of the art world, share a common thread in our artistic practices, both traversing the boundaries between the commercial and contemporary art spheres. Ken Doneâ€™s legacy serves as a beacon for aspiring creators and enthusiasts alike.â€™

Claudio Kirac is an artist living and working on the Lands of the Kombumerri families of the Yugambeh language region, Gold Coast. Kiracâ€™s practice is focused on mixed media works that explore shared experience, nostalgia, harmony and equilibrium, and the crossover between analogue and digital processes, contemporary art and popular culture.
synthetic polymer paint on canvas\n\nÂ© The artist

**Peter Hughes**  
born Australia 1982

**Miriam Vale Merlo Coffee Shop** 2023  
synthetic polymer paint on canvas

â€˜This is a portrait of me, Peter Hughes, having my medium, lactose-free cappuccino in a takeaway cup, at a cafÃ© during my holiday in Miriam Vale. Having lived in Australia my whole life, I have enjoyed many road trips to various places around the country and these become inspirational subject matter for my paintings.â€™ 

Peter Hughes is a Meanjin/Brisbane-based artist and member of Brisbane Outsider Artists whose practice is inspired by day-to-day life experiences and current events. Hughes uses painting to communicate and process his experiences, thoughts and feelings.
oil on canvas\n\nÂ© The artist

**Nick Collerson**  
born Canada 1977, Australia from 1979

**Goin' t' be like lightnin'** 2024  
oil on canvas

â€˜My painting practice is an allegorical meditation on self. I improvise with familiar motifs of the outside world to speak of common cross-cultural inner experiences that may bring people together in a shared understanding. Drawing on the tradition of poetics from the ancient world, pataphysics and surrealism, my themes include transience, journey, mystery and the life of the psyche. My painting is a metamorphic and symbolic self portrait, painted from observation and attention. During the making of this painting I had been working long hours into the night translating Aristotleâ€™s poetry on meditation. In the dawn Pan meets the Sun.â€™ 

Canadian-born Nick Collerson lives and works on Gadigal Land in Sydney. In his practice Collerson reflects on the relative nature of national, social and personal identities, deepened by his meditation practice and research into the poetics of philosophy.

labels.title: Habitat of monstera II (Self-portrait with yellow paisley jacket)
labels.subtitle: Bahman Kermany

text.content: oil on canvas\n\nÂ© The artist

**Bahman Kermany**  
born Iran 1984, Australia from 2000

**Habitat of monstera II (Self-portrait with yellow paisley jacket**) 2023  
oil on canvas

â€˜To be completely honest, I donâ€™t own a paisley jacket nor a monstera plant or even have a moustache. I fantasise what it would be like to have those things. This self portrait is part of an ongoing series where imaginative figures and landscape come together. The stylised moustache is a recurring motif symbolising my cultural heritage and imparting a hint of humour. These works ponder the purpose of the self portrait in a world where the race for fame across all types of media is on the rise.â€™

Iranian-born Bahman Kermany moved to Australia at the age of 16, and lives and works on Cammeraygal Land in Sydney. His practice engages with identity, heritage, social issues and the cultural and political conflicts of both Australia and Iran.
oil on linen\n\nÂ© The artist

**TÃ©cha Noble**  
born Australia 1977, Berlin from 2016

**Lyndal** 2023  
oil on canvas

â€˜With this portrait, I am interested in how the subject might appear to both transcend time and be embodied within the contemporary moment. Lyndal Walkerâ€™s physicality possesses this potential for me. Lyndal has a deep connection to experiencing time; in her artistic practice, she is a photographer, but also an avid diary keeper, and is currently studying ancestral healing. For this portrait, I drew on painterly references from early modernism that depict the female subject with a particular liminality between night and day, masculinity and femininity, and the boundaries of the body and what we define as nature.â€™

TÃ©cha Noble is a Berlin-based Australian artist who works at the intersection of painting, drawing, textiles, set design and live performance. As both a solo artist and with the art collective The Kingpins, her work has explored ideas around gender, identity and the body.
mascara, eyeshadow, eyeliner, foundation, lipstick on cotton muslin\n\nÂ© The artist

**Nena Salobir**  
born Malaysia 1986, Australia from 1992

**Self portrait on washcloth** 2024  
mascara, eyeshadow, eyeliner, foundation and lipstick on cotton muslin

â€˜_Self portrait on washcloth_ is an intimate portrait created by pressing a â€œpainted faceâ€ onto a commonplace cotton medium. This artwork acknowledges the self portraits so many of us paint, day in and day out, only for them to wash down the sink. In capturing traces of these acts, I recall the gentle repose of a Victorian death mask. The face is the ultimate canvas on which our innermost desires, identities, neuroses and vanities can be variously portrayed, and betrayed. This piece was created in the early hours of  
New Yearâ€™s Day 2024, perfectly bottling feelings of longing, anticipation, disappointment, insecurity and hope.â€™

Based on Whadjuk Noongar Country in Boorloo/Perth and Gadigal Land in Sydney, Nena Salobir is a conceptual artist specialising in portraiture. Her long-running project _Self portrait in society_ is a cumulative artwork consisting of portraits she draws while her subjects draw her at the same time.
watercolour on linen\n\nÂ© The artist

**Morgan Stokes**  
born Australia 1990

**Jordan Dalah** 2023  
watercolour on linen

â€˜Jordan Dalah is a wild, wild fashion designer who has this singular, dramatic vision which I respect and admire. Heâ€™s also a good friend. Since the two of us share an interest in material and materiality, I wanted to foreground the tooth of the linen and at the same time capture him in a more subdued way.â€™

Morgan Stokes is an artist living and working on Gadigal Land in Sydney. Through a conceptual approach to painting and sculpture, his work explores our existence in, and perception of, the physical world.

labels.title: Ngapartjiâ€“Ngapartji

**Tobias Titz**  
born Germany 1973, Australia from 2001

**Robert Fielding**  
Yankunytjatjara/Western Arrernte; Pakistani/Afghan heritage  
born Australia 1969

**Ngapartjiâ€“Ngapartji** 2023  
pigment photographic print on paper from Polaroid Type 665 film

â€˜In our language we say Ngapartjiâ€“Ngapartji: a process of doing things together, side by side. To give to one another, to share. This is at the core of our culture, our art centres and communities. Side by side, we work and we lead. We know that if one of us succeeds, we all rise strong. We support each other. We celebrate each other. Because we are one.â€™ â€“ Robert Fielding

Naarm/Melbourne-based Tobias Titz is a photographer and educator who has worked collaboratively with First Nations communities in the Pilbara, Kimberley, Western Desert, Arnhem Land, Tiwi Islands and Central Australia for more  
than a decade.
pigment photographic print on paper

**Naomi Hobson**  
Southern Kaantju/Umpila  
born Australia 1978

**Fragility** 2024  
pigment photographic print on paper

â€˜Micky is my cousin. Itâ€™s the middle of the wet season and in between fishing places, we were all relaxing when this beetle dropped onto his face. He was a little shocked, but he gathered himself, pulled the clinging beetle off his face and let it wander off to live yet another day. I love spending time on the river with my family. The river is filled with invertebrates; they are the backbone of biodiversity, and they call the Coen River home too. Itâ€™s a shared space. I wanted to capture this connection and show that we can all live in harmony with nature and its diversity of species. Life is fragile.â€™

Southern Kaantju/Umpila artist Naomi Hobson lives on the banks of the Coen River in Coen, Queensland. Her paintings, ceramics and photographs address the powerful and ancient links between Country and identity, and assert a strong and confident vision of her Community.

labels.title: Men of High Degree: Jim Everett â€“ puralia meenamatta (clan plangermairreenner, Ben Lomond people, Cape Portland nation, north-east Tasmania)
labels.subtitle: Brenda L Croft and Prue Hazelgrove (Wet plate collodion process technical assistant)

text.content: original wet plate collodion process tintype, pigment photographic print on paper

**Brenda L Croft**  
Gurindji/Malngin/Mudburra peoples; Anglo-Australian/Chinese/German/Irish/Scottish heritage  
born Australia 1964

Prue Hazelgrove (wet plate collodion process technical assistant)

**Men of High Degree: Jim Everett â€“ puralia meenamatta (clan plangermairreenner, Ben Lomond people, Cape Portland nation, north-east Tasmania)** 2023  
original wet plate collodion process tintype, pigment photographic print on paper

â€˜I met Jim Everett â€“ puralia meenamatta â€“ at the First Black Playwrights Conference in 1987. This was such a formative event for me, being surrounded by senior cultural and political activists and creatives. At the time Jim was producer at ABC TVâ€™s Aboriginal Programs Unit. Born on Flinders Island, Tasmania, Jim lives on Cape Barren Island. With 50 years involvement in the First Nations struggle, Jim is renowned as a creative and critical author, and producer/cultural advisor on documentary and feature films. This portrait is the second in my series _Men of High Degree_ â€“ a cultural reimagining of early 20th-century anthropologist AP Elkinâ€™s culturally inappropriate publication _Aboriginal Men of High Degree_.â€™ 

Brenda L Croftâ€™s creative-led research encompasses Critical Indigenous Performative Collaborative Autoethnography and Storywork.
pigment photographic print on paper

**Meng-Yu Yan**  
born Australia 1992

**Another ruin I** 2023  
pigment photographic print on paper

â€˜What is the place of photography in a world over-saturated with images? Instead of creating, I wanted to destroy my images, to delete everything on my camera roll. Inspired by queer photographer Jimmy DeSana, I turned to my photographs with a knife and began to cut into them. Queer representation and identity politics has become tokenising and flat. I wanted to rip into the surface of the image to reach something deeper. Photography as a medium can sometimes feel distant and removed, but here, cutting into the surface of my own image became hands-on and personal.â€™

Meng-Yu Yan é¢œæ¢¦é’° is a queer, non-binary, Australian/Chinese artist based on Wallumedegal Land in Sydney, best known for their creation of mystical dreamscapes and haunting self portraits.

labels.title: Maman Simin
labels.subtitle: Ali Tahayori
labels.medium: UV print on glass, hand-cut glass, silicone

text.content: UV print on glass, hand-cut glass, silicone on aluminium

**Ali Tahayori**  
born Iran 1980, Australia from 2007

**Maman Simin** 2023  
UV print on glass, hand-cut glass, silicone on aluminium

â€˜This is my grandmother, Maman Simin. She died recently, and this is the last photograph I took of her before she passed away. The portrait is not only an image of my maternal grandmother but also represents her as a personification of the nurturing and life-giving Mother Earth, the homeland, and all our ancestors. Looking at the image, I am reassured that she is in a good place, resting in the infinity, while praying for her children. The photograph was printed on clear glass, then broken by hand, and reassembled to create a whole that is greater than the sum of its parts.â€™

Iranian-born artist Ali Tahayori lives and works on Gadigal Land in Sydney. Tahayori uses archival materials, narrative fragments and performative approaches to explore themes of identity, home and belonging, drawing on ancient Iranian philosophies about light and mirrors.

labels.title: A million moons: Self-portrait as an Iranian woman
labels.subtitle: Sammaneh Pourshafighi

text.content: cyanotype on paper

**Sammaneh Pourshafighi**  
born Iran 1982, Australia from 1984

**A million moons: Self-portrait as an Iranian woman** 2023  
cyanotype on paper 

â€˜My series _Exposed hair_ comprises cyanotypes made by arranging hair on sensitised paper and exposing it to UV light. The hair, contributed by Iranian women in Australia including myself, symbolises solidarity with victims of patriarchy like Mahsa Jina Amini. Defying oppressive dress codes, the hair forms images of freedom and rebellion. Some pieces reflect Iranâ€™s tangled history, while others resemble celestial clouds, representing hopes for a brighter future. _A million moons_ depicts crescent moons made from my curly hair, as an expression of emotions and feminine qualities in nature. The moonâ€™s phases mark time and hold significance in Islam, particularly during Ramadan.â€™ 

Naarm/Melbourne-based Sammaneh Pourshafighi is a queer genderfluid Muslim artist. Pourshafighiâ€™s multi-disciplinary practice examines identity politics, mental health, diasporic tensions and relationships between bodies and environments from a feminist perspective.
pigment photographic print on paper

**Justin Deng**  
born Australia 2000

**Ivy** 2024  
pigment photographic print on paper

â€˜Growing up with a sibling 10 years younger can sometimes feel like peering through a time portal and seeing fragments of your own childhood. Watching my younger sister emerge from childhood and enter her early teens, I feel she struggles with many of the same problems I had both at home and in school, especially with issues which stem from being children of migrants. This portrait of Ivy was taken out in the front yard of our family home, a few days before I moved out of the house we both grew up in.â€™

Justin Deng is a Naarm/Melbourne-based photographer. His practice reflects on his Chinese/Australian cultural upbringing, and the complicated feelings that arise when navigating this transcultural identity.
pigment photographic prints on paper

**Amos Gebhardt**  
born Australia

**Alexis with moon** 2024  
pigment photographic prints on paper

â€˜In this portrait, acclaimed Waanyi author Alexis Wright is lit solely by moonlight. As Alexis is a storyteller who dares to imagine future cosmologies in these dystopian times, I sought to pair her with the elemental power of the moon, a symbol of dreams and illumination. Reflected in Alexisâ€™ eyes are tracings of the moon itself created through subtle movement of the human body in dialogue with the Earthâ€™s rotation.â€™ 

Artist Amos Gebhardt lives and works on Kaurna Country in regional South Australia. Gebhardtâ€™s practice is epitomised by a commitment to agitating dominant narratives around marginality, representation and more-than-human ecologies.
pigment photographic print on paper

**Shea Kirk**  
born Australia 1985

**Alfie Barker (right view)** 2023  
pigment photographic print on paper

â€˜The feeling of being as at home in my body as I did before I went through puberty is indescribable. Transitioning for me has been like un-doing as much of puberty as I can, back to who I was before I went through school. Before I knew what was expected of a female to wear and do and act like. Before school made me wear a dress every day. Before I was thrown into a society obsessed with rules on gender and the expectations that came with that. I am so proud every day that I made it back at age 24.â€™ â€“ Alfie Barker

  


Shea Kirk is a Naarm/Melbourne-based artist working with traditional photographic methods and techniques. His studio-based practice and collaborative methodology enables his sitterâ€™s articulation of self. Kirk was the winner of the 2023 National Photographic Portrait Prize.
pigment photographic print on paper

**Saville Coble**  
born Australia 1974

**New Gold** 2024  
pigment photographic print on paper

â€˜This is a portrait of Dr Christian Thompson AO, a contemporary visual artist and a Bidjara man of the Kunja Nation. The gold lightly painted across his face is a reference to the lesser-known side of his Chinese-Australian heritage and to â€œXin Jin Shanâ€, which is how the first wave of Chinese immigrants referred to the gold rush in Australia. Thompsonâ€™s paternal grandmother, Harriet Woods, is a direct descendant of the Chinese migrants who immigrated during the Victorian gold rush in the early 1850s. This lineage guides us to his current work and shows how the past creates his new inspiration.â€™

Saville Coble is a Naarm/Melbourne-based photographer from King Island, lutruwita/Tasmania who works across commercial and art photography.
digital type C print on paper

**Juliet Taylor**  
born Australia 

**Teenagers 2024** 2024  
digital type C print on paper

â€˜The older I get, the more I appreciate teenagers. Rihanna and Erika, my nieces, are the epitome of teenagers in 2024. Their authenticity, naivety, exploration. The many â€œfirstsâ€, untainted. The paralax between being comfortable and uncomfortable within themselves. The complex relationships. These challenges form their own identity.â€™

Juliet Taylor is an artist based on Gadigal Country in Sydney who sources her inspiration in unlikely places â€“ from Miroslav TichÃ½ to Charles Bukowski, Le Corbusier to SÃ©bastien Tellier.
pigment photographic print on paper

**Zoe Helene Karouzos**  
born Australia 1993

**Mikayla with her brothers** 2023  
pigment photographic print on paper

â€˜It was hot down at the river. Jax waded into the water, his mum yelling at him to come back and get into the photo. Four siblings, all tired from the night before, looked at me through my lens. I remembered what it was like to feel as though everything my parents asked me to do was a burden, and I knew that later in life Mikayla and her brothers would be grateful for these moments together.â€™

type C print on paper

**Phoebe Kelly**  
born Australia 1996

**Tay, in our garden (2024)** 2024  
type C print on paper

â€˜My housemate Tay Haggarty on the cusp of returning to Queensland after two years living in Melbourne. A role model not only as an artist, but through their total openness, gentle nature and humour with which they move through the world. I wanted to document Tayâ€™s time in our home, among the veggie patch theyâ€™ve tended to through their time living here, capturing a home that has held them through a period of growth and change.â€™

Phoebe Kelly is an artist living and working in Naarm/Melbourne who is interested in the ways photography can suggest traces of invisible forces. Her practice focuses on the desire to hold or preserve the ineffable and the loss bound to this.
pigment photographic print on paper

**wani toaishara**  
born Democratic Republic of Congo 1990, Australia from 2012 

**witness** 2023  
pigment photographic print on paper

â€˜nameless hands that toil  
steadfast and true,  
whispers of strength in their touch  
rest,  
assured.â€™

wani toaishara is an artist based in Naarm/Melbourne whose practice explores Black life and representation, dislocation and Indigeneity as well as the effects of colonialism on Africa and its diaspora. Through his work he interrogates the complexities of Black sociality in urban spaces, often using his personal history to create intimate works.
pigment photographic print on paper, kiln cast glass frame

**Tamara Henderson**  
born Canada 1982, Australia from 2019

**Green in the Grooves** 2023  
pigment photographic print on paper, kiln cast glass frame 

â€˜This self portrait is a 16mm film still taken from Green in the Grooves. The film focuses on the close observation of microbiology in compost soil, and the chemical and insect-driven processes of decomposition and earthworm ecology. In this photographic frame I was under a pane of glass and soil was progressively scattered onto the glass. In the moving picture the image progresses from being of the sky to an opaque but reflective surface â€“ via the application of soil. It is a moment that depicts a body which is under the earth and in reflection simultaneously.â€™ 

Tamara Henderson is an artist based on Ngunnawal/Ngambri Country in Kamberri/Canberra whose work draws attention to the often-unappreciated earth beneath our feet, the grounding of life on this planet.
pigment photographic print on paper

**Angela Tiatia**  
born Aotearoa/New Zealand 1973, Australia from 2012

pigment photographic print on paper

It is a testament to the sacrifices and struggles that her generation endured when they migrated to the cities of Australia and Aotearoa from the villages of the Pacific Islands in the 1960s. I had a very clear idea of the presence of the person I was looking for to embody my mother in this image. After months of searching with no luck, finally a friend messaged me Cassaereaâ€™s Instagram profile. She was perfect: strong, calm, resolute, captivating.â€™

Based on Gadigal Land in Sydney, artist Angela Tiatia explores contemporary culture, drawing attention to relationships between representation, gender, neo-colonialism, the commodification of body, history and place.

labels.title: â€˜Aishah!â€™ Self-portrait with my mother. Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia
labels.subtitle: (Nur) Aishah Kenton

text.content: pigment photographic print on paper

**(Nur) Aishah Kenton**  
born Singapore 1998, Australia from 2016

**'Aishah!' Self-portrait with my mother. Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia** 2023  
pigment photographic print on paper

â€˜I struggle to assert myself as an adult with my mother. When visiting family in Malaysia, her natural dominance often overshadows my own independence. I have tried to change the dynamics of our relationship but have never found the right way to achieve this. Recently I started photographing my family, and my mother is very happy to be involved. Without the camera I am her daughter, however with a camera I feel more equal, more myself around her. The medium helps me explore our relationship and observe how we change when the act of photography is at play.â€™

(Nur) Aishah Kenton is a Malay/Australian artist and educator based in Naarm/Melbourne. Kentonâ€™s practice is often collaborative and examines personal, social and cultural life experiences.
pigment photographic print on paper

**Shelley Xue**  
born China 1995, Australia from 2018

**é˜¿è°Š (ah Yi)** 2023  
pigment photographic print on paper

â€˜After three years apart, three precious weeks reunited me with Mum. I felt Iâ€™d never truly seen her as herself; as her anxieties, fears, regrets and affections had been shielded from view, so that she could become the mother of mine. Yet, for the first time, tear-stained, she told me stories I had never known. She exuded childlike joy among orchids and succulents. Her hand sought mine on our walks. Youâ€™ve loved as much as you can, Chunyi. And Iâ€™ve started to see that now, Mother.â€™

Naarm/Melbourne-based Shelley Xue is an artist from Guangdong, China whose photographic project _Unknown solitariness_ is a visual exploration of human and non-human aloneness.
pigment photographic print on paper

**Arini Byng**  
born Australia 1987

**(indistinct chatter) 3** 2023  
pigment photographic print on paper

â€˜_(indistinct chatter) 3_ is an intimate and personal work, which pictures an improvised duet between my father Travis Byng and myself. Together we move vulnerably and tenderly, negotiating each otherâ€™s limbs, with the subtle tensions inherent in the shared discovery and exploration of cultural and familial themes. The title refers to a caption seen in films, when multiple conversations are taking place but no particular dialogue is discernible. Here, this background conversation is brought centre-stage, without reducing the exchange to a retelling for voyeuristic eyes. The viewer is invited both to consider the specificity of my family narrative, and how we all handle and perceive our own memories, histories and experiences.â€™

Naarm/Melbourne-based artist Arini Byng explores the affective qualities of materials, gestures and settings to negotiate political scenes and navigate experiences of identity, history and memory.
pigment photographic print on paper

**Dean Cross**  
Worimi  
born Australia 1986

**Old growth/New growth** 2023  
pigment photographic print on paper

â€˜This image was made in an old growth forest in a secret corner of Walbunja Country near Braidwood, NSW, four days before the birth of our twins. Both photographer and subject are on a precipice; our world was about to change forever. Like the seed that preceded that giant tree, our boys contain a universe and that universe is contained within my wife Bridgette. The joy she possessed in that moment has carried through every day of being with our boys; a mother blossoming like the small white flowers of the tree behind her.â€™

Based on Walbunja Country, Dean Cross is an artist and Worimi man through his paternal bloodline. He is interested in the collision of materials, ideas and histories, and enacts First Nations sovereignty through expanded contemporary art methodologies.

labels.title: Nyangatja Ngayuku Mara (These are my hands)
labels.subtitle: Rhett Hammerton

text.content: pigment photographic print on paper

**Rhett Hammerton**  
born Australia 1981

**Nyangatja Ngayuku Mara (These are my hands)** 2024  
pigment photographic print on paper

â€˜Ngayuku marangku, ngayulu waraka pulka tjuta palyani. Ngayulu anangu tjuta alpamilani, titjtjarangku. Ngayunku mama, ngangkari pulka mulapa, paluru ngura iriti wiyaringku. Paluru ngayunya nintinu ngangkari-tjanku anangu tjuta ngangkaritjanku. Paluru ngayulu tjunu uwankaru paluru kanyitja, ngayuku marangka ngangkari nyinatjaku. Ka anangu tjutangku, ngayuku photo nyakula, tjana nintiringi ngayuku tjurkupa munu ngayuku warka pulka mulapa Ngangkari palyatja tjuta mulapa.

I work with my hands, doing important Ngangkari work. Iâ€™m helping people with my hands all the time. My father, he was a famous Ngangkari, but he passed away a long time ago. He taught me everything I know about healing people. He put the special healing properties into my hands. When people see my photo, they will learn about my story, and about all the important work that Ngangkaris do.â€™  
â€“ Maringka Burton, Pitjantjatjara artist and Ngangkari (traditional healer) 

Rhett Hammerton is based between Meanjin/Brisbane and Mparntwe/Alice Springs. His practice is underpinned by respect, collaboration and creativity.
pigment photographic print on paper

**Tace Stevens**  
Noongar/Spinifex  
born Australia 1992

**We Were Just Little Boys** 2023  
pigment photographic print on paper

â€˜In 2023, I received a grant from the Magnum Foundation and the World Monuments Fund to work with the Survivors of the Kinchela Boys Home, a state-run institution that kidnapped hundreds of First Nations boys between 1924 and 1970. Dhungutti man Uncle Harry Ritchie (#56) shares his story: â€œI didnâ€™t learn anything about Aboriginality. We were taught to be white in there, you know what I mean? Taught to be white, and donâ€™t mix with blackfullas in school. I lost my culture ... more or less, my identity ... I knew nothing when I got out of Kinchela. When I went to Mumâ€™s in Armidale, I cried to go back to Kinchela, because thatâ€™s all I knew. That was my home, you know?â€â€™

Tace Stevens is a Noongar and Spinifex visual storyteller based in Boorloo/Perth. She uses photography and film to explore this world, and to better understand who she is as a First Nations woman.
pigment photographic print on paper

**Luke Currie-Richardson**  
Mununjali/Butchella/Djabugay/Kuku Yalanji/Samsep Meriam  
born Australia 1988

**Through a child's eyes** 2023  
pigment photographic print on paper

â€˜As I perch upon the electrical box on the corner of Swanston and Little Bourke, I watch tens of thousands of protesters stream by me like a river trying to divert the course of history. As I look out over the sea of signs, my height allows me to see free above all. I look directly down to these eyes in a deep gaze observing me for a fleeting moment before moving along with the current of the sea.â€™ 

Luke Currie-Richardson is a Naarm/Melbourne-based artist. Currie-Richardson shares vital and groundbreaking stories of First Nations resistance, joy and solidarity through multi-artforms such as dance, film, photography, spoken word and fashion.

labels.title: She
labels.subtitle: Prue Hazelgrove
labels.medium: original wet plate collodion process tintype, pigment photographic print

text.content: original wet plate collodion process tintype, pigment photographic print on paper

**Prue Hazelgrove**  
born Australia 1995

**She** 2023  
original wet plate collodion process tintype, pigment photographic print on paper

â€˜Existing can be an act of defiance. When my wife Junia first saw this image, she didnâ€™t see herself. It was distressing and disappointing. But the more we both sat with the portrait, the more we saw her. She is determined and afraid to be known. She is vulnerable and powerful. She is becoming and has always been herself.â€™ 

Prue Hazelgrove is a queer artist based on Ngunnawal/Ngambri Country in Gundaroo. Hazelgrove specialises in the 19th-century wet plate collodion process, which they use to represent stories erased from conventional narratives, asking viewers to consider their biases and beliefs.
pigment photographic print on paper

**Daniel Temesgen**  
born Ethiopia 1999, Australia from 2019

**Joy** 2023  
pigment photographic print on paper 

â€˜Joy is about finding the positive nourishment within oneâ€™s self and others which, in a safe and healing environment, allows you to stand as your original self. It allows you to stop time â€“ and stop chasing after societyâ€™s view of being great â€“ just to take a deep breath as your true self no matter the situation you are put in. That is JOY, that is being yourself. The names of the models are Dut, Tana and Laurancio.â€™ 

Ethiopian-born, Naarm/Melbourne-based Daniel Temesgen is a portrait photographer whose work aims to connect with his surroundings and showcase the beauty of culture and diversity.
pigment photographic print on paper

**Paul Knight**  
born Australia 1976, Berlin from 2019

**Untitled (Chamber Music)** 2023  
pigment photographic print on paper

â€˜My photographic series _Chamber Music_ explores, without confines, the relationship I share with my partner, Peter. A direct strategy in this work is that we both make ourselves vulnerable to the camera and to its way of seeing. In this spirit, the camera has equal access to both of us and our shared life. The evidence of intimacy and connection that the image presents is a testament to the camera and the resultant imagesâ€™ ability to be a container and simultaneously act as an index of the cognitive need for love and intimate recognition between people.â€™

Paul Knight is a Berlin-based Australian artist whose work takes intimacy as its primary theme, including the vast space it creates in social lives, and the importance intimacy plays in the development and construction of people as intellectual beings.
pigment photographic print on paper

**J Davies**  
born Australia 1994

**S & T in the window** 2023  
pigment photographic print on paper

â€˜On the third floor of a converted warehouse in the heart of Collingwood, Surej and Tom embrace one another in the frame of what the apartmentâ€™s residents refer to as The Smoking Window. The contorted web of limbs protruding out from bare bodies creates an affectionate nest for nurturing, comfort and closeness. This private moment, happening behind closed doors and in open windows, is an invitation into Surej and Tomâ€™s own personal, sensual and sensuous celebration of queer intimacy â€“ the image welcomes a wider audience to contemplate their own experiences with intimacy, in its many forms and contexts.â€™

Based in Naarm/Melbourne, J Davies is a Takataapui (queer, trans, MÄori) artist using photography to document their life and their queer whaanau. In their ongoing practice  
of archiving contemporary queer existence, they explore themes of identity, intimacy and neurodiversity.
pigment photographic print on paper

**Garry Trinh**  
born Vietnam 1975, Australia from 1980

**Tom Polo** 2023  
pigment photographic print on paper

â€˜I had the opportunity to visit the studio of Tom Polo, an Australian abstract painter whose works are full of vibrant colours and shapes. I wanted to capture his essence in a portrait that would reflect his artistic vision. I didnâ€™t plan anything in advance, but rather let my creativity and instinct lead the way. We tried different poses until we stumbled upon the idea of abstracting his face. The result was a portrait that merged Tomâ€™s face with the style of his paintings, creating a striking visual harmony. It was all done in camera.â€™

Garry Trinh is an artist based on Wangal Country in Sydney who makes art about the uncanny, unexpected and spontaneous moments in daily life. His works are inspired by his surroundings and visual expressions of contemporary culture.
pigment photographic print on paper

**Jo Duck**  
born Australia 1985

**Stripe search** 2023  
pigment photographic print on paper

â€˜_Stripe search_ is a staged portrait of a woman hiding in plain sight. â€œSusanâ€ is trying to evade the facial recognition technology that tracks our every move. People born in the internet age have likely been tracked since birth. Everywhere we go weâ€™re recorded without consent. Governments have used facial recognition drones to track criminals, leading to wrongful arrests and a myriad of ethical concerns. I decided to approach this subject with humour instead of fear as we enter an uncertain AI-influenced future. Defying the typical format of a portrait, â€œSusanâ€ is attempting to hide from view, melting into stripes.â€™

Jo Duck lives and works in Naarm/Melbourne. Driven by an appreciation for all things camp, joyful and absurd, Duckâ€™s photography centres on crafting unique characters who live confidently in worlds of their own.

labels.title: Where does your body end and mine begin?
labels.subtitle: Madeline Bishop

text.content: pigment photographic print on paper

**Madeline Bishop**  
born Australia 1991

**Where does your body end and mine begin?** 2023  
pigment photographic print on paper

â€˜This work of long-term friends Pat and Alan comes from a collection of images displayed in small sequences. The camera remains static and repeatedly captures a scene from one angle, while the subjects move around the room, trying to enact the same pose over and over.â€™

Madeline Bishop is a Naarm/Melbourne-based photographer whose work is conceptually centred around personal dynamics and the persistent tension between distance  
and closeness.
pigment photographic print on paper

**Andrew Babarczy**  
born Australia 1971

**Arlen spinning?** 2023  
pigment photographic print on paper

â€˜This is a portrait of my son Arlen, lying on our living room floor one afternoon. Totally spontaneous, the decision to take the photo was inspired by the shape of his body. As I stood on the couch to frame the shot, Arlen raised his arm to cover his eyes from the flash. Upon viewing the developed image I was intrigued. Arlen appeared to be simultaneously still, and also spinning in mid-air. I have presented this image as a diptych in both orientations as it further enhances the sense of intrigue.â€™

Andrew Babarczy is a Naarm/Melbourne-based photographer whose work is raw, intimate and often speaks to human connection.
pigment photographic print on paper

**Emma Armstrong-Porter**  
born Australia 1986

**Read the Room** 2023  
pigment photographic print on paper

â€˜I was diagnosed with Autism at age 30. Now 37, I find every day Iâ€™m learning more about how my brain diverges from the norm, especially in my relationships  
with other people â€“ 1) I love hard; 2) Iâ€™m very impulsive; 3) I canâ€™t â€œread the roomâ€. Not until I developed the film did I see the tortured look on my partner Jessâ€™ face. In that moment, I had really thought that they were happy to see me. Iâ€™ve learned that the camera doesnâ€™t lie, it reflects reality, but rarely does it tell the whole story.â€™ 

Emma Armstrong-Porter is an artist and educator who lives and works on Dja Dja Wurrung Country in Maldon, Victoria. Armstrong-Porter is known for their work across printmaking and chemistry-based photography.
pigment photographic print on paper

**Katrin Koenning**  
born Germany 1978, Australia from 2003

**Reinhold** 2023  
pigment photographic print on paper

â€˜In May 2023, Papa caught a plane to see me in Naarm/Melbourne for one day and one night. We looked at art, walked a little, ate, took trams and sat by the river. It was the first time he had come to visit on his own since losing Sharon, his partner of 23 years.â€™ 

Katrin Koenning is a Naarm/Melbourne-based artist who uses photography as an encounter to explore relationships. Pursuing intimacy and interconnection, Koenning uses fragments and slippages to suggest narrative spaces and communities that are fluid and multifaceted.
dye sublimation print on aluminium

**Annabelle McEwen**  
born Australia 1997

**Bio-identifier_1** 2023  
dye sublimation print on aluminium

â€˜As content circulates and technology extracts resources, the body has become a data asset. Interrogating the surveilled and commodified body, I speculate on how its extraction is shaping epistemological shifts in our technological-milieu and future. As reality is flattened into semiotic data-streams, I question how the definition of the self is distorted via the power of images. This portrait uses photogrammetry software, synthesising several photos to construct a biometric copy of myself. Employing methods of intervention, I mimic the mediation individuals face via our data-powered virtual identities.â€™

Annabelle McEwen is an artist based on Gadigal Land in Sydney who uses photography, printmaking and digital technologies to examine the impact of digitally mediated experiences on users and the virtual gaze on the body.
digital photograph on paper

Bangardidjan, Cindy Rostron from Korlobidahdah, a strong inspiring young leader and proud Kune, Rembarrnga, Dalabon woman of the Bonongku and Wurrbban clans, on the road in remote Central Arnhem Land in the family muddikkang (car) with a buffalo skull painted by her father Victor Rostron strapped to the roof.

labels.title: blood/memory: Brenda & Christopher I (Gurindji/Malngin/Mudburra; Mara/Ngarrindjeri/Ritharrngu; Anglo-Australian/Chinese/German/Irish/Scottish) 2021
labels.subtitle: Brenda L Croft and Prue Hazelgrove (Photographic Assistant)

text.content: original wet plate collodion process tin-type, digital scan to Ultrachrome pigment on 100% cotton rag paper

blood/memory: Christopher is my son/great-nephew/grandson, I am Christopher's mother/great-aunt/grandmother. His great-grandmother is my father's older sister. They shared the same non-Indigenous father, different First Nations mothers, but still looked like peas in a pod. Our combined bloodlines include Gurindji/Malngin/Mudburra peoples and Anglo-Australian/Chinese/German/Irish for me, Mara/Ngarrindjeri/Ritharrngu and Anglo-Australian/Irish for Christopher. My grandfather/Christopher's great-great-grandfather's journey into the Northern Territory over a century ago is reflected in this portrait. It is a gift to share Christopher's life and I learn from him every day â€“ blood/memory. Marntaj.
digital photograph on paper
I took this photo of Shirley at her daughter's house while she was relaxing in the sun. Shirley is proud of her 89-year-old body.
digital photograph on paper
We see with our eyes, but also our hearts. When I photographed Perrin Marie, I wanted to show her what I saw. A Warrior. A Muse. A Nomad. A Seeker. An Angel. A Survivor. An Artist. What do you see?
digital photograph on paper

For the past year I've been returning to the Bexhill Quarry on the outskirts of Lismore documenting the people and ecosystems within its parameters. The location, with its aqua blue water nestled under towering sandstone cliffs, is an abandoned brickworks quarry that has become a popular swimming destination for both locals and tourists.

The quarry serves as a constant backdrop to an ever-evolving microcosm, bearing witness to people coming and going, the flora blooming and dying, and the landscape shifting and changing â€“ evoking a sense of 'place' as temporal and rhythmic in a more-than-human world.

This is a portrait of local boy, Brody, in the water.

labels.title: Boyca dharraka mayung ngurr gartji. Lardum ratjuk gurr (Boyca at Mayung Creek, Gartji. Hunting for barramundi)
labels.subtitle: Cassandra Scott-Finn

text.content: inkjet print on paper

Boyca Durrurrnga is a young YolÅ‹u boy, born in Gove and living in the Ramingining community, North-East Arnhem Land. He loves hunting barramundi, stingray and kangaroo. His Dreaming is the Brolga and Butterfly from his mother's side, and the Rainbow Serpent from his father's side. Many years ago, a young YolÅ‹u girl was taken by a crocodile at Mayung Creek right near where Boyca was standing in this photo, so we were very quiet and respectful while visiting Gartji.
digital photograph on paper

The 2022 Eastern Australia floods were one of the nation's worst recorded natural disasters. Intense rainfall quickly broke riverbanks, swamped roads, claimed homes, businesses and lives.

Ty and Jake paddle down Strong Avenue on a journey to find a friend's passport. That morning they'd rescued another friend's puppies. Graceville was one of the many affected Brisbane suburbs. The damage was widespread. As people started to emerge from shelter, Queenslanders began one of the biggest recovery operations in the state's history. 

In reality, human-caused climate change is warming the atmosphere, oceans and intensifying heavy rainfall events like this.

labels.title: Ukrzaliznytsia (Ukrainian Railways) employee, Sumy Oblast, Ukraine
labels.subtitle: Adam Ferguson

text.content: digital photograph on paper

Olha Trypolska, duty manager at the Trostianets train station in Sumy Oblast. When Russian troops invaded Trostianets in February 2022, Olha, along with seven people, hid in the basement of the train station, where this portrait was later taken. Since Russia's invasion of Ukraine, trains have become the backbone of the country: essential to the war effort, crucial to evacuating people, moving weapons, goods and supplies, as well as providing a diplomatic avenue and an economic lifeline.
digital photograph on paper

KAHA in Maori means to be a strong warrior, and this is what Vicky has been. Two years ago Vicky suffered burns to almost 60% of her body. Her Rarotongan legs and Kiwi mana got her through 18 surgeries, eight weeks in a coma and over seven months in hospital. Vicky had no photos or mirrors in her house and wanted a photo showing her inner strength and beauty.
digital photograph on paper

'I've always struggled with the size of my body from being extremely underweight to now being overweight. Over the past few years working with other photographers, making portraits, I've been processing my feelings about the transformation and how my body fits within society. I've begun to reclaim my skin, by designing symbols about my life so far that Iâ€™ve been getting tattooed. Iâ€™m starting to feel more at home in my big queer body.'\n\nThis portrait of Ruby is half of a stereoscopic pair from the ongoing project _Vantages._
glicÃ©e print on paper

Derek is an image from 'Bloodlines', a multi-artform series honouring legendary artists silenced by the AIDS epidemic of the 1980s and 90s. Shining beacons who helped shift the worlds of queer art and culture into new realms. This work honours Derek Jarman, multi-disciplinary artist whose art presented a searing vision of homosexuality and high art. Due to AIDS-related illness Derek's vision was fractured by the colour blue. With this work we channelled his unrepenting portrayal of queer sexuality and the history of the male nude in queer art. This work is a testament to his vision, his beauty and his bravery.
type C photograph on paper

When I first saw this stranger, who I came to know as Stanley, I was struck by the likeness to a medieval angel â€“ with a cloud of blonde hair. Letting hair grow over the pandemic, Stanley emerged from two years of lockdowns defiant. This portrait of Stanley speaks of this dual emergence; from adolescence into adulthood but also moving from an all-encompassing period of lockdown into a newer, freer self.
digital photograph on paper

I met Madison de Rozario, an Australian Paralympic athlete and wheelchair racer, in 2022 when I was asked to photograph her for a magazine. We bonded over the feelings â€“ like that of longing â€“ that come with travelling often due to our jobs, where travel is necessary and required. It started raining while I was taking her portrait but we decided to seize the moment, and I like how I captured the shared sentiment in this one.

labels.title: Self portrait with my mother and sister
labels.subtitle: Anne Moffat

text.content: digital photograph on paper

We planted the eucalyptus tree as a seedling when we first moved into this house in the suburbs of Melbourne, and it has grown alongside our family, weathering many seasons over the years. I made this self portrait with my mother and sister by the flowering tree, wearing my grandmother's beautiful patterned cheongsam that we brought back to Australia after she passed away. The resulting image sits at the intersection of my Asian lineage and 'Australian' identity and encapsulates elements that hold deep significance for me and my family.
digital photograph on paper

Portrait of my aunty Helen Garner. Taken on medium format film, at our family reunion at my dad's home in Ruffy, Victoria. Helen's work as an author celebrates the beauty that is inherent in ordinary moments, and I wanted to capture her in a similarly unspectacular act. Here she is shutting the gate to keep her daughter's dog, Smokey, away from the spit roast being prepared for dinner behind me. I only took one photo as I could tell that Helen had revealed herself to the camera as she does in her writing â€“ with rawness, vulnerability and strength.
digital photograph on paper

Set among the tough slums of Kyazanga, Uganda, _Ugandan Ssebabi_ is a photographic tribute to the world's greatest underdog. Godfrey Baguma, who was born with a rare and painful physical disability, was abandoned by his mother as a bringer of 'bad luck', and shunned by society. Through a chance encounter, he reinvented himself as an entertainer in a travelling show. Now 57, he has beaten the odds. While most people with his condition die by 40, he has found love, success and bought a house â€“ a testament to human resilience and positivity.
archival pigment print on paper

While the camera is conventionally claimed to possess a unique capacity for revealing something of a subject to its viewer, in _Mirror II_ I instead perform an act of queer photographic dis/appearance. My figure is concealed beneath a spectacular costume that mutually entices and resists examination, while the image terrain is manicured to become implausibly shallow and aglow. This double bind of a figure conspicuously produced for the lens yet unable to be seen â€“ hiding in plain sight â€“ reflects my interest in the potential for queer representational in/visibility in which subjects are empowered to pass before the camera un/seen.
digital photograph on paper

_Looking Down_ characterises the experience of powerlessly watching the world change around you.\n\nSamantha is reminiscent of a guardian angel, youthful yet wise beyond their years, staring in sombre melancholy upon the earth.
digital photograph on paper

Anne Clarke is a young Miriuwung women from far north Western Australia. She lives on a small farm with her mum and sister, just outside the remote town of Kununurra. This portrait shows Anne in spurs and a LeBron James basketball singlet. Anne's dream to work in the pastoral industry reflects a long tradition of Aboriginal stockwomen; her LeBron James singlet a nod to the growing influence of American culture. A complex mix of the past and present.
type C photograph on paper

_Last Summer Days_ is almost autobiographical, an exploration of images that address my own fear of time and its passing. It started with hundreds of undeveloped rolls of film of my family; some dating back as far as 2002. Too scared to process them I eventually started the arduous task of unfurling them. What I found were those innocent, seemingly simple times of youth â€“ that magical crease in time where anything seems possible, before cynicism and the weight of the world is felt so acutely. This current work follows Lola, at that precarious transition from adolescence to the melancholic heaviness of adulthood.
digital photograph on paper

Dave Gerry is a proud Indigenous Australian. Born in Alice Springs, he was fostered from a young age and grew up with his brother in the leafy Melbourne suburb of Glen Waverley. Dave never met his birth parents but loved his foster parents fiercely. Recently, he was contacted by a blood brother he never knew he had. That brother is Harold Thomas, the artist who created the Australian Aboriginal Flag. Dave is an observer. Patient and quiet, he's content to watch on â€“ especially if it's sport. And yes, the moustache is inspired by his Aussie cricketing heroes of yesteryear.
digital photograph on paper

Having a distinct passion for the conservation of pandas being held in captivity, Jaye lived and worked in China for several years. She collaborated with zoos all across the provinces and made efforts to create a better standard of living for pandas.

labels.title: Portrait of My Mother As An Ethno-Futurist Icon
labels.subtitle: Sammaneh Pourshafighi

text.content: digital photograph on paper

An ethno-futurist perspective asks 'Who are we? Where do we come from? Where are we going?' It seeks to answer these questions by creating a bridge between the national and the international, between and beyond the collective pasts and futures of our ethnic culture. This is a portrait of my mother Maryam, an Iranian migrant and Australian citizen. She is a keeper of our familial ancestral knowledge, as well as an enduring advocate for diasporic Iranian culture, having established the first Persian language school on the Gold Coast, Queensland. I wanted to capture Maryam's colourful personality and dedication to future thinking, alongside her transcultural identity.

Davide Di Giovanni is an extraordinary individual. He is a dancer, a choreographer and the director of New Old Now, an emerging artistic collective. And he was a gift, someone who sees your vision. The images that we made together were his vision too. I love the way he knew exactly what I wanted.
digital photograph on paper

Marawa is a Los Angeles-based, 12-time Guinness World Record holding Hula Hoop Master and a very good friend. Marawa and I met while she was a student at the National Institute of Circus Arts and I was a photography student. Since then, we have collaborated for years, making bizarre photographs in Sydney, Melbourne, Adelaide, LA, New York, Blackpool, London and Paris. This image was taken in Melbourne after not seeing each other during the pandemic. The reunion with my long-time collaborator and kindred spirit brought great joy. No one literally throws themselves into it like Marawa.

labels.title: In my dreams I am dirty, broke, beautiful & free.
labels.subtitle: David Cossini

text.content: digital photograph on paper

During the bitterly cold English winter, I was staying in a squalid and dangerous squat in the middle of London. Niall became my self-appointed protector. Every morning I would wake to Niall either curled up in a ball at the end of my bed or sprawled out on the floor with his head resting on the mattress like it was a pillow. He would assure me that he was keeping me safe.
digital photograph on paper

Rodney Hobbs, known by many as Riverboat Rod, has devoted a lifetime to building model paddle steamers. He builds each model by hand in a workshop a short walk from the banks of the Murray River. Each model takes hundreds of hours to construct. Rod's grandmother worked and lived on a paddle steamer, and her stories inspired him to begin recreating these boats. Ruby is his favourite.
inkjet print on paper

Award-winning stage and costume designer Kristian Fredrikson worked on productions for ballet, opera, contemporary dance, theatre, film and television. He began his 40-year partnership with The Australian Ballet in 1964 and collaborated regularly with Graeme Murphy for the Sydney Dance Company (SDC), Melbourne Theatre Company and Opera Australia. On the 50th anniversary of the SDC in 2019, Murphy recollected that dancer and co-artistic director of the SDC Janet Vernon would hang Frederiksonâ€™s costume illustrations on her dressing room mirror. â€˜They were so exquisitely drawn that when she was doing her make-up and psyching up for the show, they would take her straight into the world she needed to inhabit. Itâ€™s wonderful when a costume is not something you throw on but a doorway to the character you become on stage.â€™\n\nPeter Brew-Bevanâ€™s portrait shows the designer at home, surrounded by shelves overflowing with books and CDs. Notoriously private, Fredrikson looks at the camera with one hand covering half his face.
inkjet print on paper

Choreographer and dancer Graeme Murphy AO was co-artistic director of the Sydney Dance Company (SDC) with his wife Janet Vernon AM from 1976â€“2007, helping it to become one of Australiaâ€™s most successful dance companies. At 14 he was the youngest male dancer to be accepted into The Australian Ballet School; he went on to dance with The Australian Ballet, Englandâ€™s Royal Ballet and Les Ballets FÃ©lix Blaska in France. Over the years he has created productions for companies including Opera Australia, Shanghai Ballet and the Metropolitan Opera, New York. \n\nLewis Morley took this photograph during Murphyâ€™s first year as artistic director of The Dance Company (as the SDC was then known). Over four decades with the company, Murphy created a repertoire of more than 50 works. He explained his creative process during a 2020 conversation with David McAllister: â€˜It comes out of the deepest recesses of my subconscious, my movement, and if it doesnâ€™t relate, then I donâ€™t have a continuity within.â€™
inkjet print on paper

Steven Heathcote AM is Principal Repetiteur and National Touring Associate at The Australian Ballet and was the companyâ€™s longest-serving principal artist, from 1987 to 2007. He has also appeared in the film _Maoâ€™s Last Dancer_, directed _Julius Caesar_ for Victorian Opera, and choreographed _Tosca_ for Opera Australia. When interviewed in 2016 for _The Australian Ballet: The Ballet Men Issue_, Heathcote described the physicality of dance. â€˜One of the things I always loved was that pursuit of athleticism, pushing hard physicallyâ€™ he said. â€˜I really enjoyed roles like Romeo, because itâ€™s highly physical â€“ the partnering, but then also the sword-fighting and all that boy stuff. I used to love that.â€™

labels.title: James Vu Anh Pham and Tara Jade Samaya from 'The Knowledge Between Us'
labels.subtitle: Pippa Samaya

text.content: inkjet print on paper

Dancers James Vu Anh Pham and Tara Jade Samaya have performed with major dance companies in Australia and around the world, including working together at Melbourneâ€™s Chunky Move with acclaimed Dutch choreographer Anouk Van Dijk. This image was taken during the shoot for the award-winning 60-second dance film _The Knowledge Between Us_, produced by the Samaya Wives. \n\nPippa Samaya explores the physicality of dance against the natural landscape in many of her films and photographs. Interviewed for _RealTime_ in 2017, Pippa described the role of dance in her work: â€˜dance allows me to capture things that are outside of myself and itâ€™s purely visual. Dance provided me a visual language for all those complex, inner emotional states of being human. It enabled me to express things that words canâ€™t and allows a level of empathy thatâ€™s otherwise difficult to find.â€™
inkjet print on paper

As part of the series _Lit by volcanos_, dancer Tara Jade Samaya was photographed by her wife and creative partner Pippa Samaya on a volcano in the Canary Islands during the Australian 2019â€“20 bushfires.â€˜This shoot was a reflection on being so far from home while our home was on fire. There is a suspension, dispersal, and desperation in this. It was a technical push for both of us, just using the natural world and the human body. What we achieve together in this photography of dance comes from our shared trust, language, values, aesthetic, and lives together.â€™
inkjet print on paper

Dancer and choreographer Paul White worked for over 20 years as a performer and artistic collaborator with companies around the world. Since moving to Germany to dance with Tanztheater Wuppertal Pina Bausch in 2011, he has performed with Leipzig Oper Ballet, DV8 Physical Theatre, Chunky Move, Australian Dance Theatre and the Queensland Ballet Company. â€˜I think the key to growth is following passion. Iâ€™m not driven by â€œsuccessâ€, said White in a 2014 interview with _DanceTabs_. â€˜Iâ€™m more into connecting with people, and sharing something with them through performance.â€™
inkjet print on paper

Wakka Wakka/Gangulu man Andrew Toby, aka Balla Neba, is a choreographer, artist and director. â€˜I grew up in an inner-city suburb where my cultural heritage was denied,â€™ says Balla Neba. â€˜As I grew, experienced life and explored I was blessed with knowledge and wisdom imparted from Elders across the country. Using this knowledge along with my natural creative gift Iâ€™ve been able to develop a unique style of dance expression.â€™
inkjet print on paper

After dancing with the Australian Dance Theatre and the UK-based DV8 Physical Theatre, Tanja Liedtke became an award-winning choreographer. She tragically died aged 29, on the eve of becoming the youngest director of Sydney Dance Company. To commemorate Liedtkeâ€™s life and work, her partner Sol Ulbrich and fellow dancers staged a world tour of her works _Construct_ and _Twelfth Floor_. As Ulbrich noted in the 2011 film _Life in Movement_, â€˜Thereâ€™s a lot to be said for giving everyone a chance to still speak through her voice. This is the thing that theyâ€™re left with, that they hold in their bodies.â€™\n\nThis photograph was taken during Liedtkeâ€™s performance in the Australian Dance Theatreâ€™s production of _Birdbrain_, directed by Garry Stewart.
inkjet print on paper

Since meeting at a dance aged 14 and 16, Pamela and Colin have continued to bond over their love of dancing.  


â€˜Dance is very special to us because it is how we met almost 70 years ago ... the intimate old style of dancing, that is, holding close, enables us to continue to express our love for each other in this very unique way. Weâ€™re two old people who are still very much in love after almost 70 years, as a result of enjoying the love and respect of our wonderful family and friends.â€™

Pamela and Colin McPherson
inkjet print on paper

Marilyn Rowe AM OBE is a former prima ballerina and the first graduate of The Australian Ballet School to become its director, from 1999 to 2014. Promoted to Principal Artist in 1970, Rowe danced all major roles in The Australian Balletâ€™s repertoire and had several works created for her by leading international choreographers, including _Gemini_ (Glen Tetley), _The Merry Widow_ (Ronald Hynd) and _Anna Karenina_ (AndrÃ© Prokovsky). In an article for _Ausdance_ in 2000 Rowe recalled, â€˜My mother took me to my first ballet class at the age of 6. I was a very shy child, reserved, self-conscious and rather timid, but when I began dancing classes I found a new strength and confidence in myself.â€™
inkjet print on paper

Wajarri Yamatji woman Telphia Joseph was photographed by Wiradjuri/Kamilaroi artist Michael Riley as part of his series of portraits capturing the vibrant First Nations arts community of Sydneyâ€™s inner west. Joseph trained as a dancer at the National Aboriginal and Islander Skills Development Association (NAISDA), established in 1976 by Carole Johnson. NAISDA has launched the careers of many First Nations dancers, including Stephen Page, former artistic director of Bangarra Dance Theatre. â€˜NAISDA is a rich place of learning and cultural connection â€¦ and continues to create tremendous young artists and Iâ€™m proud to say many are an integral part of todayâ€™s Bangarra.â€™
inkjet print on paper

Dancer and choreographer Janet Vernon AM was co-artistic director of the Sydney Dance Company from 1976 to 2007 with her husband Graeme Murphy. In the early years they often danced together. Later, she danced with the company throughout the world, in roles and productions they had created together. In a 2015 interview with Kang Yena on _The INNERview_,Vernon said of working with dancers: â€˜Itâ€™s beautiful when you get a breakthrough. They own the movement really because no one else has done this. Itâ€™s just them and their body. I think once they can accept that, and start to feel more comfortable, itâ€™s a wonderful feeling as a dancer when you suddenly find a new way of moving, a new freedom, a new voice.â€™
inkjet print on paper

Director, choreographer and curator Gideon Obarzanek founded Victorian contemporary dance company Chunky Move, and is co-director of the New Melbourne Festival. Obarzanek began his career as a dancer with the Queensland Ballet and Sydney Dance Company before switching to choreography. As he recalled in an interview with _Dircksey_ in 2018, â€˜[Choreography] was a bit of therapy at The Australian Ballet School to restore my self-esteem. I was quite behind in that course and one of the teachers said, â€œwhy donâ€™t you apply yourself to some choreography of dancing that you think you could do well?â€ I was only really a professional dancer for five years, I moved into choreography very quickly.â€™
inkjet print on paper

Meryl Tankard AO is a dancer, choreographer, filmmaker and dance theatre director. A former dancer with The Australian Ballet and the Tanztheater Wuppertal Pina Bausch in Germany, she was also artistic director of Adelaideâ€™s Australian Dance Theatre. Renowned for her distinctive choreography, when interviewed by Paul White in 2008 for _DanceLife_, Tankard said, â€˜I look for a great openness of mind and body â€¦ For me whatâ€™s important is WHY we move ... Iâ€™m not really interested in a whole lot of great technical moves if it doesnâ€™t touch you somehow emotionally. So I guess it is about being honest and true to yourself.â€™
inkjet print on paper

At the age of sixteen Sir Kenneth Gillespie joined the Borovansky Ballet in Melbourne, before performing as a lead dancer internationally with the likes of the Royal Ballet, Ballets Russes de Monte Carlo and New York City Ballet. In 1960 he founded the Tasmanian Ballet School, where he taught a young Graeme Murphy, and established Tasmaniaâ€™s first professional ballet company in 1974. â€˜I learned dance in the small stable which Kenneth transformed into a studio,â€™ Murphy said in a 2010 interview in _The Examiner_. â€˜I loved his vision, his glamour, his refinement. He was extraordinary â€¦ Your first teacher is like your first love â€“ they leave an indelible mark on your life â€“ Kenneth Gillespie is that teacher for me.â€™
inkjet print on paper

Anna Pavlova was principal artist of the Russian Imperial Ballet, beloved for her famed creation of _The Dying Swan_. After forming her own ballet company in 1911, Pavlova performed to great acclaim around the world. Her company of about 40 dancers made two tours to Australia in 1926 and 1929.  


As a teenager, Robert Helpmann danced with the legendary ballerina on her first Australian tour. In an interview with Hazel de Berg for the National Library of Australia he described the dedication and hard work of the great dancer: â€˜I used to go to the theatre at half past five and standing on a barely lit stage covered in woollen tights and pullovers and shawls would be this lonely figure practising â€¦ I often wonder whether the audience realised for one second the amount of work you have to do to become an Anna Pavlova.â€™ 

While Pavlova avoided the press, she commissioned leading Australian photographer Harold Cazneaux to photograph her while performing in Sydney. In this portrait she is posed backstage in costume for _Don Quixote_.
inkjet print on paper

Danish prima ballerina, choreographer and teacher HÃ©lÃ¨ne Kirsova was a founding member of the Ballets Russes de Monte Carlo. She first visited Australia on tour with the Ballets Russes in 1936, returning to Sydney two years later. In 1941 she established Kirsova Ballet, the first professional ballet company in Australia. In a 1940 _Sydney Morning Herald_ article about the opening of the school she said, â€˜there is plenty of talent here. There is also a great deal of appreciation for the ballet, and I think that appreciation can be intensified by greater knowledge of the tradition and meaning of balletâ€™. Kirsova created original ballets and was an important patron of Australian composers, set designers, artists and photographers. A similar photograph of Kirsova featuring the shadows of a rope pulley backstage, also by Dupain, as published in _The Home_ magazine in 1938.

labels.title: Ngarrga Jawandaji Dancing for The Sandridge Band Performing Their Song Ngabaya (Spirit People) at the 2021 Malandarri Festival, Yanyuwa Country 2021
labels.subtitle: Benjamin Warlngundu Ellis Bayliss

text.content: inkjet print on paper

Gadrian Hoosan, a Garrwa and Yanyuwa musician and lead singer of The Sandridge Band, was photographed by Gudanji/Wambaya man Benjamin Warlngundu Ellis while performing at the 2021 Malandarri Festival in Borroloola, Northern Territory. Known for their rock/reggae blend, the musicians sing in their Garrwa and Yanyuwa languages. 

â€˜The children are dancing to our song, _Ngabaya,_ about the spirit people. Itâ€™s traditional dance, traditional song with modern music. Every time we perform everyone knows the song, everyone knows how to dance. Itâ€™s a story about the land. Theyâ€™re all connected to the land.â€™  
Gadrian Hoosan

labels.title: Wandangula Dancers & the Song People Perform Ngabaya (Spirit People) at the 2014 Malandarri Festival, Yanyuwa Country 2014
labels.subtitle: Benjamin Warlngundu Ellis Bayliss

text.content: inkjet print on paper

Wandangula dancers Linda McDinny and Rachel McDinny, and the Wandangula song people, performing at the 2014 Malandarri Festival in Borroloola, Northern Territory. â€˜This _Ngabaya_ dance, he been travel all lah [sic] way from Western Australia to my Grandmother Country,â€™ says McDinny. â€˜My Grandfather he was showing that dance for us, he was dancing with them, he was dancing and showing them kids how to dance. Thatâ€™s all they did.â€™
inkjet print on paper

At the Laura Quinkan Dance Festival in Far North Queensland, communities across the Cape York Peninsula come together to celebrate with music, dance, singing and cultural performances. Wayne Quilliam has been photographing the festival for over 20 years. â€˜Each performance is a platform of commentary, of sharing stories that have been handed down by Indigenous people since the spirits created the land,â€™ Quilliam says. â€˜The Elders share the knowledge: the young carry our hopes.â€™
inkjet print on paper

Wayne Quilliam took this photograph at the You Yangs in Victoria, where dancers from across the state gathered to prepare the children for their Naming Ceremony. â€˜In its purest essence the evolution of culture connects us to Country, it inhales and exhales with us, has a heartbeat, and sings songs for all to hear,â€™ says Quilliam. â€˜Listening to the Elders share the stories with the young ones as they prepare ochre for ceremony provides connection to a new entity of self, time, place and cultural consciousness.â€™
inkjet print on paper

This photograph was captured on the Bora (initiation) ceremonial grounds at the You Yangs in Victoria, where dancers from across the state gathered to prepare children for their Naming Ceremony. â€˜This image transcends the western narrative of â€œtraditional cultureâ€, responding directly to the shared experiences of people and culture in modern society,â€™ says Quilliam. â€˜For generations our people have adapted to the constantly changing landscape. The evidence of this shines through in this young dancer practicing culture with her bionics.â€™
inkjet print on paper

Alfira Oâ€™Sullivan founded Suara Indonesia Dance in 2001. She sees one of the principles of Acehnese dance, a traditional style from Indonesiaâ€™s northern province, â€˜is to dance as one body, with one soulâ€™. Here dancers perform _Rapai Geleng_, a seated Acehnese dance that combines body percussion,hand drumming and singing. They work together to keep in rhythm, throwing the drum in the air for the next person to catch. Describing the interrelatedness of dance, Suara Indonesia dancer and choreographer Amelia Darmawan said, â€˜Dance connects your feet to the earth, your heart to each other and your soul to something greater.â€™

labels.title: Daniel Riley choreographing Hit the FloorÂ Together with QL2 dancers
labels.subtitle: Lorna Sim

text.content: inkjet print on paper

Wiradjuri dancer and choreographer Daniel Riley became the first First Nations Artistic Director of the Australian Dance Theatre in 2022. Riley began his career with Canberra youth dance company QL2 before becoming a senior artist with Bangarra Dance Theatre, from 2007 to 2018. \n\nSpeaking of the role of dance in First Nations culture in a 2021 _ABC News_ article Riley said, â€˜Iâ€™ve been able to continually explore my cultural identity and my heritage, and dance is a big part of storytelling. It doesnâ€™t matter what culture or language you speak. It is a universal language. Itâ€™s how we all connect to something. Through dance, I just found my voice.â€™

labels.title: Dance for Wellbeing 'Dancing With Alzheimers' at Belconnen Arts Centre
labels.subtitle: Lorna Sim

text.content: inkjet print on paper

Dance for Wellbeing is a program initiated by Philip Piggin at the Belconnen Arts Centre, Canberra. Jacqui Simmonds leads a Vivacity class for people living with dementia and their care partners. 

â€˜Itâ€™s all about the dancers sharing a love of movement and having a joyful interaction with their partners in a safe, inclusive space. I can see that they are being touched by the music and expressing that through their bodies. Itâ€™s a privilege to dance with them and to see them leave the class smiling, more energetic and often with a higher sense of awareness.â€™  
Jacqui Simmonds

labels.title: Brooke Lockett, Heidi Martin, Karen Nanasca and Halaina Hills, NYC
labels.subtitle: Lisa Tomasetti

text.content: inkjet print on paper

During their 2012 tour of the United Sates, The Australian Ballet dancers Brooke Lockett, Heidi Martin, Karen Nanasca and Halaina Hills performed as the infamous four cygnets in Graeme Murphyâ€™s critically acclaimed _Swan Lake_, wearing costumes designed by Kristian Fredrikson.\n\nLisa Tomasetti photographed the dancers at the busy intersection of Lexington and 6th Avenue in New York City. In Tomasettiâ€™s 2020 photobook, _The Australian Ballet on the International Stage_, Lockett recalled the challenges of such a shoot: â€˜Imagine the hustle and bustle of New York, 4 Aussie ballerinas, and a photographer with the energy to stop traffic and pedestrians to get the shot.â€™
inkjet print on paper

David McAllister AC was director of The Australian Ballet from 2001 to 2020. Over three decades with the company, McAllister was celebrated for his extraordinary performances as a dancer and led The Australian Ballet to become one of the most highly regarded dance companies in the world. In an interview with Richard Fidler in 2019 for _ABC Conversations_, McAllister described a childhood love of dance: â€˜I was always dancing around â€¦ my first memory was waiting for _Play School_ and dancing in front of the TV with tea towels tucked into my pants and spinning â€¦ it was destined that I was going to dance.â€™

labels.title: Ghenoa Gela in â€˜Winds of Woerr'
labels.subtitle: Gregory Lorenzutti

text.content: inkjet print on paper

Ghenoa Gela is a proud Torres Strait Islander woman and award-winning multi-disciplinary, multi-dimensional storyteller. â€˜What I love most about dance is that it transcends time,â€™ says Gela. â€˜For _Winds of Woerr_, Mum and I connected with a story from our past, _Woerr,_ a sacred rock. By combining _Woerr_ and the _Four Seasonal Winds_ we created a new contemporary story in the present. And by sharing the knowledge and story through dance, we have created a connection to the future.â€™
inkjet print on paper

Yumi Umiumare is a Japanese Butoh dancer, choreographer and teacher. This image was taken during a dress rehearsal of _ZeroZero_, a dance work in collaboration with Tony Yap and Matthew Gingold performed at the 2014 Melbourne Festival. â€˜I remember the moment when Gregory got close to me and took this shot,â€™ says Umiumare. â€˜I felt quite fragile as Iâ€™d been very busy with many arts projects, slightly overwhelmed both mentally and physically. But when touching the clean water and seeing my reflection, this sensation shifted to a gentle feeling of relief and calmness melting into the image of my own face.â€™

labels.title: Dancenorth Australia (Gideon Obarzanek & Lucy Guerin) Samantha Hines, Mason Kelly, Jenni Large, Ashley McLellan, Josh Mu, Georgia Rudd and Jack Ziesing
labels.subtitle: Gregory Lorenzutti

text.content: inkjet print on paper

Choreographed by Gideon Obarzanek and Lucy Guerin, _Attractor_ brought together Queenslandâ€™s Dancenorth Australia with Indonesian music duo Senyawa. 

â€˜This work for me has been a succumbing to the inherent power of music and dance and how they can propel each other into heightened states of energy, tone, rhythm and form. I have always believed that we can watch dance without having to translate it into a meaning beyond what we see and experience.â€™  
Lucy Guerin

labels.title: Collaboration â€“ Sam Goraya, \nSantosh Ram and Samir Kumar Panigrahi backstage before a performance of Kundalini: The Awakening!
labels.subtitle: Zlatko Varenina

text.content: inkjet print on paper

Sam Goraya, Santosh Ram and Samir Kumar Panigrahi keep the Indian classical dance Odissi alive through performances such as _Kundalini â€“ The Awakening!_ Here they are pictured applying makeup before a show at the Melbourne Theatre Company.\n\nâ€˜Putting make up on and getting into a character reflects how we take on different roles in our daily life and perform to the best of our abilities to achieve a harmonious outcome,â€™ says Goraya. â€˜A collaborative approach to achieve a common goal by providing guidance and support to one another as one does in real life within family and friends.â€™
inkjet print on paper

Wangkatjungka actor and dancer Ningali Lawford-Wolf began her career with the Aboriginal Islander Dance Theatre, before joining Bangarra Dance Theatre. She tragically died while on tour with the Sydney Theatre Companyâ€™s adaptation of Kate Grenvilleâ€™s _The Secret River_.
